newsitem.title: USA: Cook County may consider hosp. debt plan in July.
newsitem.headline: Cook County may consider hosp. debt plan in July.

text.p: Cook County, Ill., commissioners will defer consideration of a policy to write off bad debts accumulated at its public health facilities Tuesday, a spokesman for board President John Stroger said.

Cook County lawyers have not completed a review of the new policy, which will allow the hospital to write-off an estimated $1.036 billion of uncollectable debts amassed at its public hospital in Chicago from 1975 to 1992, spokesman John Gibson said.
It will likely be brought for approval at the Cook County Board's meeting scheduled for July 1, Gibson said.
Cook County has not had a policy for writing off uncollectable hospital debts and the new plan will allow the Bureau of Health Services to clear the books when all efforts have been exhausted.
Patients have amassed another $270 million of debts for services rendered since 1992 as well.
